comments.text:
+Jordan Maynard
Just to clarify, when you experience the effects of adrenaline you are 
basically more alert. You pay attention to more detail, your senses are on 
high alert, and most importantly your reaction time is increased and 
everything in your body goes faster. So basically, because you are so aware 
time SEEMS to go slower because it takes less time for impulses to travel 
from your sensors to your brain (and back again of course). This is why 
flies/mosquitoes can react quicker to things such as your hand trying to 
squish it, because they are smaller and impulses have much less distance to 
travel. This is also why flies live shorter lives because although for us 
it seems like 2 days is short. For them it may seem like months if not 
years.

However, what the scientists have done is conduct and experiment on 
Einsteins theory of relativity. According to Einstein TIME ITSELF slows 
down for you (even though it feels like time is passing by normally) the 
faster you go. This is not the way you perceive time but "one second" 
physically becomes longer for you. They use what is called an "atomic 
clock" which is a special type of clock that detects the radioactive decay 
of a certain element (i think carbon) and uses this decay time as a 
measurement of time. I.e the time it takes for 1 gram to decay is equal to 
a certain amount of time. The time it takes for 1 gram to decay however 
slows down the faster the atomic clock is moving.

So you confused perception of time with ACTUAL time.

because i don't believe in souls. (Don't disbelieve either.) But if you 
travel back in time, it means reversing the time flow, aka everything 
happening in reverse. 

So if you want to teleport your current self to the past instead of 
adjusting your worldview, you got two options.
a) Keeping "your" molecules from floating out of your body and yourself 
from thinking, acting and aging backwards or
b) creating a copy of yourself in the past.
In both cases you end up with a body made of atoms which really should be 
somewhere else. You already changed the past simply by existing. So to 
escape the time paradox, the changed timeline has to have exactly the same 
outcome as the original one. Therefore you have to reverse all changes; 
erasing yourself in the process and making your visit utterly pointless. 
(unless you find a way to send things or information to your original 
future without affecting your original present)
Also there is the whole matter of utilizing energy that was not in a usable 
state at the appropriate time.

But there is a way out. You are able to create or erase the same amount of 
matter and antimatter with no energy at all, because they cancel each other 
out. (Don't ask me how to do it, it's one outdated explanation for the big 
bang). As long as you somehow keep them in the same place, you don't 
interact with gravity. 
If you now accomplish invisibility to touch and electromagnetism as well 
while still being able to perceive anything, there is no reason not to time 
travel.

comments.text:
+Trace Dominguez
 Atom excited -> the energy helps the electron with just enough energy to 
go up an orbit but not break free of the atom -> strong force was holding 
it -> strong force quickly wins over the 'just enough' energy leading to 
bringing the electron back to its normal orbit -> energy is released in the 
form of light -> its the force at which the photon is emitted and its 
structure that does not interact with most other stuff that ensures that it 
keeps going at a constant speed through space.
'If' an atom is made to go at the speed of light, it would mean that the 
strong force won't be strong enough to bring the electron back to its 
normal orbit and one can imagine that the electron would also not be able 
to change state. I imagine this phenomenon can be called as a Matter Freeze.
'If' an atom is made to go at a speed that is slightly slower than the 
speed of light then the strong force will win but at a slower rate and it 
will take a long time for the electron to jump back to its normal state and 
the light to be emitted.
This tells us how the time slows down for the atom going at a high speed. 
And in other words how it affected the speed at which it can change state.
In case of atomic clocks, the atoms whose resonance frequency is used for 
measuring time, resonate at a slower speed. But the clock as a whole is in 
a single frame going at the same speed and thus every atom of which the 
clock is made of resonates slower and 'measures' slower. Thus, ISS clock 
ticks slower compared to earth clock.
Basically the speed affects the rate at which matter can change - change 
instantly or freeze.

Time doesn't really exists? - well, any system that changes state at a 
regular interval (absolute or perceivable) can be said to have time. Be it 
the atoms' resonance frequency or the sun rise and sun set. In that sense 
time exist. Its a property of a system, just like number is. Its the 
property that exist.

I believe it would be fun to see the effect of speed on radioactive 
elements. The radio active decay would not happen after a certain speed. It 
should be possible to calculate the speed at which that would happen.

Time slows down for the 'thing' that is going at a high speed. Like in case 
of this German experiment the time slowed down for the ion that was going 
at the high speed. The ions environment i.e. instrument, lab, earth, solar 
system, milky way galaxy was going at the slower speed and was ticking at 
its own rate. Thus, your title of the video is misleading "How scientist 
can slow down time", however an attentive person would figure out that 
scientist slowed down the time of a few ions. The title would have better 
been "How scientist slowed down time for a few ions.". That way people with 
non scientist brain can understand the concept.

comments.text:
I think you're focusing on the wrong thing here. It's not the atoms or the 
clocks, or the speed, it's the idea of time and relativity. Time was 
invented to help us break up the day, it doesn't actually exist. It's all 
about our perception relative to each other. Measurement is relative. 

Theoretically, as I understand it, traveling at the speed of light your 
molecules are changing state, water would melt, fire would burn, everything 
would FEEL normal. If you were going 0.95 light speed and turned on a 
flashlight, it should still shine out ahead of you like normal at the speed 
of light, because it's not exceeding light speed relative to itself, only 
relative to something stationary nearby.

If you were on the shuttle, you'd feel normal, just as if you were the 
stationary observer. But the way our devices MEASURE time will be altered 
RELATIVE to each other. Atomic clocks use a specific number of atomic 
vibrations to measure one second (an arbitrary measure of time). The 
vibrations in the shuttle clock atoms RELATIVE to the atoms in the ground 
clock would appear to vibrate the same if you're standing next to them, but 
differently RELATIVE to each other.

Sidebar: Technically, the clock on the ground is ALSO MOVING because the 
Earth is moving through space... This got me thinking so much that I made a 
whole video about it. Coming soon!! :D
comments.author: Trace Dominguez

on Earth. (They're only about 420 km up, so they're close enough to Earth 
that the effects of special relativity are dominant.  GPS satellites, 
orbiting higher and faster, actually run slightly faster than ground clocks 
due to general relativity.)

top_comment.text:
So what happens to time now that we can stop light by freezing it for a 
minute?﻿
top_comment.author: Sergio Estrada

comments.text: +Matthew Prorok Nice!!! Thanks for clarifying!
comments.author: Sergio Estrada

comments.text:
Basically.  Massless particles, like photons, always travel at the speed of 
light.  It is impossible for them to do otherwise, just as it is impossible 
for particles with mass to travel at the speed of light.  Any time light 
passes through a material, what is actually happening at the quantum scale 
is that photons (moving at c) are being absorbed by the electrons around 
the atoms in that material, the energy of which kicks them into an excited 
state.  Those electrons then settle back into their ground state, releasing 
a new photon, which travels (again at c) to another atom, repeated over and 
over.

In the "freezing" of light, what you do is shine a laser through a material 
that is transparent (i.e. that passing of photons from atom to atom is very 
fast and easy and occurs in the same direction the light was originally 
travelling, so the light doesn't scatter), but only under certain 
conditions.  Then, you change the conditions while the laser is going 
through so that the transparency shuts off.  This traps the electrons in 
the excited state they were in at the time.  But while that is the case, 
the light isn't in the form of photons; the energy is stored in the excited 
electrons.  It doesn't become light again until those electrons are allowed 
to drop back to their ground state, releasing the energy in the form of 
photons and "unfreezing" the light.
comments.author: Matthew Prorok

comments.text:
+Matthew Prorok Interesting. So it is instantly converted into something 
else, frozen, and then converted back to light?
comments.author: Sergio Estrada

comments.text:
+Sergio Estrada Nothing.  Because we can't.  During the time that light is 
"frozen", it ceases to be light.  It is instead the energy of a photon or 
photons stored in the excited state of an electron or electrons.
comments.author: Matthew Prorok

comments.text:
+tigerija That's a view known as presentism, and it's almost certainly 
false.  It is impossible to say that two events occur at the same time if 
they are at different points in space.  Because of this, what I observe as 
occurring in the present, you might not have experienced yet, and it is 
thus in your relative future.  A third observer might have already seen the 
event, and thus it is in their relative past.  The only way to make sense 
of this is that the event occupies a fixed point of space-time coordinates, 
and whether that's past, present, or future depends on your coordinates. 
 Which means that the event must exist eternally.  

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relativity_of_simultaneity

comments.text:
What regulates perception of time:
The perception of time is based on the measuring/perception mechanism. 
Human brain has a simple mechanism and can track time only to a certain 
degree of accuracy. However, it is capable of making other mechanism that 
are accurate. Atomic clock is a such a mechanism. I believe scientist are 
confusing people :) Here is what I think it is. Understand what exactly is 
time - if there is something that occurs at a regular period then the same 
can be used to tell time. Humans started telling or perceiving time using 
(in increasing order of accuracy) (1) brain's internal clock namely 
suprachiasmatic nucleus, (2) using periodic sun rise and sunset, (3) 
mechanical clock, (4) digital clock, (5) atomic clock.

What effects does it have on the person: None

Some more thoughts:
Imagine there was nothing that occurred at a regular interval and 
everything was chaotic. In that case there won't be any time! Which means a 
universe where there is space (or something equivalent) but no time - ah! 
no space-time, no time travel, no nothing! But that's not the case with our 
universe, many things are periodic i.e., deterministic and thus there is 
stuff and there is time. But, many things occur at different period, what 
would be 'the time' against which all other time can be compared? Imagine 
that there is one type of entity that is the smallest of all things we know 
and it has some property that occurs at a regular period, that would be the 
absolute time of the universe. It also implies it keeps ticking on its own 
pace and thus time can neither be slowed down or fast forwarded. Only thing 
that can happen is travel time can be increased on decreased by increasing 
or decreasing the speed at which you go. But the speed is the key to 
slowing/increasing age of a thing. Note (a) light is emitted when energy is 
released from an atom. (b) things in motion stays in motion until you know 
when. That means if you throw something at a certain speed (i.e. at a 
certain force) in to space where there is nothing to slow it down then it 
will keep going at that constant speed at which it was projected. Combining 
(a) and (b) one can tell that the light has its speed because it is the 
force by which energy is released from an atom. That implies that 'if' an 
atom is made to travel at the speed of light then it cannot lose energy and 
it will remain in its original state. So 'if' a person travels 1 light year 
(distance) and come back he/she wouldn't have aged a bit because his/her 
atoms had no chance to age. But it took 1 light year to go and 1 light year 
to come back i.e. time kept ticking, neither did it stopped nor did it 
slowed down. 2 light years time had passed by but his/her atoms had no 
chance to age so for him/her no time passed by and thus from his/her point 
of view time hadn't even ticked whereas the absolute universal time kept 
ticking. If a person travels half the speed of light then his/her atoms 
would have a chance to change state, which means he/she can perceive the 
time to be passing and it would be a small bit. Thus its the speed that is 
the key, time actually doesn't slow down.

If you were able to travel faster than the speed of light, I do not think 
that would mean that you would age backwards. Since time is relative, even 
though everything around you may have gone back in time, you yourself 
wouldn't feel like you were going back in time. A good way to put this 
would be if you took a watch with you while you went into a *Warp Drive*, 
the time on the watch wouldn't go backwards, but if you had a clock back 
home let's say, theoretically (correct me if I'm wrong) it should infact go 
backwards.

By Warp Drive I'm referring to an idea proposed by Miguel Alcubierre (also 
known from Science Fiction i.e. Star Trek) that would allow for effective 
faster-than-light travel by collapsing the space in front of an object, and 
expanding it behind that object, to propel it faster than the speed of 
light, and thus would allow for backwards-in-time-travel, since you would 
arrive at destinations technically before you left. As Slender Mane 
mentioned, this would require negative mass which would require negative 
energy of which is extremely hard to acquire for the context of a Warp 
Drive.

Sources:

Warp Drive: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alcubierre_drive

How we might be able to achieve this negative energy density I talk about: 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Casimir_effect

Some say a lot of the issues regarding a possible Warp Drive could be 
tackled by a better understanding of how General Relativity relates to 
Quantum Mechanics (Since they do not account for each other), hence Quantum 
Gravity: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_gravity

Please correct me if I'm wrong in the above mentioned, I'm not exactly a 
Physicist, just a high-school nerd with a passion for Physics and too much 
time on his hands.

comments.text:
+Tespri
Whether you think of it as a concept or a property of a system, time does 
exist. Since you can measure it you can't deny its existence. The atomic 
clock uses the resonance frequency of a particular atom, because the 
frequency is known. We map that time to the time as if know. And yes, we 
use it because it is more accurate than the cycles of our Sun or the 
frequency of the crystals in our digital clocks. Now to your question "How 
does movement of atoms = time exists?". First of all it is not the movement 
of atoms, it is the change of state of atoms. My understanding is that the 
speed at which the atoms travel through the fabric of space determines how 
fast or how slow they can change state. And various small factors add up 
and lead to visible effects at a high level. That's why, the airborne 
atomic clocks ticks slower, it is not just the atom whose resonance 
frequency that is used to measure time that changes state at a slower rate, 
its the whole apparatus (clock) that changes state at a slower rate and 
thus measure time at a slower rate. And it is not just the clock, its the 
airplane that carries the clock and the human beings that are in the 
airplane, all of their atoms change state at a slower rate and they in fact 
came back younger compared to their age if they hadn't flew. And the age 
difference would be the same as the time difference that was measured 
between the earth clock and the airborne clock. Man (or woman), you have to 
accept the fact that Einstein was a scientist and not a crazy person and he 
knew exactly what he was talking about when he said space and time are not 
different and they need to be looked upon as a single entity, as in 
space-time. If you still think time does not exist then all you need to do 
is read more,  see more and think more. One fine day you will get the idea.

If it were possible, which there is no reason to believe it is. Relativity 
predicts that as they approached the speed of light the objects in their 
view would appear to move faster and faster in time. to an outside observer 
the traveler would appear squished almost flat perpendicular to the 
direction of motion. to the traveler they would not notice a change in 
their own width, but would perceive the change in width in objects that the 
traveler was passing by. objects in front of the traveler would appear blue 
shifted and objects that the traveler had already passed would crowd around 
the perimeter of the field of view appearing as red shifted. The passage of 
time would seem regular to the traveler, but relative to a stationary 
outside observer the travelers passage of time would be slower and slower 
as he approaches the speed of light. At the speed of light the traveler 
would no longer experience any passage of time they would essentially be 
frozen in time like a snapshot. I am not sure if they would be observable 
from the outside because their mass should theoretically become infinite 
which is infinitely more mass than what is required to create a black hole.

captions.text:
The faster you move the slower time goes,
but… how slow? And how fast? What does it
all mean!?!

Howdy nerds and friends, thanks for checking
out DNews today, I'm Trace. There are things

about theoretical and mathematically-proven
physics that are difficult to see in practice,

but of those things… there is one that is
no longer simply theoretical, we can actually

DO it. Einstein's Theory of Special Relativity
states that the faster something travels,

the slower time appears to move relative to
a stationary observer.

To test the time dilation part of the TSR
massive experiments had to be conducted. In

1971, the Hafele (ha-fi-la) and Keating Experiment
flew four atomic clocks on airplanes going

around the world and compared the time-shift
from those clocks to the atomic clock at the

National Observatory in Washington, D.C.,
and JUST like Einstein predicted the airborne
clocks were going SLOWER.

Think about it. When you're on an airplane,
you're aging slower than your Mom. Unless

of course, she's on the airplane too…. as
long as we're thinking about it, time dilation

theory says airline pilots might be aging
slower than their ground crews… think about
it. Not a lot slower, mind you, but slower.

Once we started going to space, time dilation
became a thing we actually had to deal with.

GPS satellites, for example, are 20,000 km
up going 14,000 km/hour. So, relative to an

observer on the ground, the GPS satellites
are going to lose about 7 microseconds per

day! It doesn't seem like a lot, but knowing
PRECISELY what time it is, is extremely important

for measuring your exact location on the planet.
If they let this go unchecked GPS would fail,

so they have to correct for Special Relativity,
just so I can find the nearest Shake Shack.

Usually, before now, scientists used mathematics
or space travel to test these out-there theories.

Special relativity says, the faster you go,
the slower time goes. If you travelled a year

at 95% the speed of light; you'd age one year,
and people on Earth would age 3.2 years! But

if you were going 50% the speed of light it
would only be 1.15 years. The effect get's
stronger as you go faster.

A German study published this week has shown
you can create the time dilation effect IN

THE LAB! Which is HUGE news for physics. The
experiment, published in Physical Review Letters,

explains how these German scientists used
a heavy ion storage ring to accelerate charged

lithium particles to almost 40 percent the
speed of light. A storage ring is sort of

like the ghost containment box in Ghostbusters,
but for charged particles.

Once the ions were travelling at top speed,
the scientists shot two laser lights at them,

one in front and one behind, and then measured
the light absorption rate. Think of it like

sonar or radar, they're measuring the amount
of energy that comes back… Because they

had two lasers and the speed of light is constant
-- they could use the Doppler[a] effect // rrreeeerrrrr

// to figure out the time dilation those ions
were experiencing. DAMN that's complicated.

If you want to read a full explainer, check
out Ars Technica.

The reason this is so huge, is because we
don't have to measure the changes on spacecraft,

or use assumptions related to the movement
of planets or astronomical bodies. On top

of that, it verifies, yet again, that Einstein
was a badass, and the Standard Model of Physics
is accurate.

What do you think of news like this? Interested?
Excited? Anything else you want to know about
speed and time dilation?

Speaking of speed, thanks once again to Subaru
for making this episode possible. Especially

the all-new 2015 Subaru Legacy. Every sedan
has its benefits, but only one combines them
all. It’s not just a sedan. It’s a Subaru.

But, back to time dilation, it seems like
we just started DNews and we're almost to

1 million subs! If you're watching this, and
you haven't yet subscribed, please take a

sec and hit that sub button, and share this
with your friends. Even if you don't, we still
love you. And thank you SO much for watching.

title: How Scientists Can Slow Down Time
